elastic¶

Created on Mon Jun 27 14:40:09 2022

@author: pmetz1

pymls.elastic.Stroh¶

class pymls.contrast.Stroh(cij: ndarray | None = None, crystalSystem: str | None = None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Elastic aspects of the dislocation contrast factor obtained by solution to the Stroh formulation.

Reference¶

Ting, T.C.T. (1996) Elastic Anisotropy. ISBN 9780195074475

property A¶

Stroh eigen vectors (3,3) obeying \(a_{\alpha+3} = \bar{a}_{\alpha}\) (i.e. half the roots of the sextic equation) \(A = [a1, a2, a3]\) (NB column vectors) (c.f. Ting eqn. 5.5-4 & 5.3-11)

property B¶

\(B_{ij} = 1/2 i \sum_{\alpha}(A_{i \alpha} M_{\alpha j} - \bar{A}_{i \alpha} \bar{M}_{\alpha j})\) ref: Stroh (1958) Dislocations and cracks in anisotropic elasticity pp. 631

property L¶

Stroh eigen vectors (3,3) obeying \(l_{\alpha+3} = \bar{l}_{\alpha}\) (i.e. half the roots of the sextic equation) \(B = [b1, b2, b3]\) (NB column vectors) (c.f. Ting eqn. 5.5-4 & 5.3-11)

property M¶

\(M_{\alpha i} L_{i \beta} = \partial _{\alpha \beta}\) ref: Stroh (1958) Dislocations and cracks in anisotropic elasticity pp. 631

property N¶

c.f. pp 144 Ting, Elastic Anisotropy.

fundamental elasticity matrix (Ingebrigtsen & Tonning, 1969)

\[\begin{split}N = \begin{bmatrix} N_1 & N_2 \\ N_3 & N_1^T \end{bmatrix}\end{split}\]
property N1¶

c.f. pp 144 Ting, Elastic Anisotropy.

\[N_1 = -T^{-1} R^T \ \ [-]\]
property N2¶

c.f. pp 144 Ting, Elastic Anisotropy.

\[N_2 = T^{-1} \ \ [m^2 \cdot N^{-1}]\]
property N3¶

c.f. pp 144 Ting, Elastic Anisotropy.

\[N_3 = R T^{-1} R^T - Q \ \ [N \cdot m^{-2}]\]
property P¶

Stroh eigen values (3,) obeying \(p_{\alpha+3} = \bar{p}_{\alpha}\) (i.e. half the roots of the sextic equation)

property Q¶

c.f. pp 137 Ting, Elastic Anisotropy.

\[ \begin{align}\begin{aligned}Q_{ik} = C_{i1k1}\\\begin{split}Q = \begin{bmatrix} C_{11} & C_{16} & C_{15} \\ C_{16} & C_{66} & C_{56} \\ C_{15} & C_{56} & C_{55} \end{bmatrix}\end{split}\end{aligned}\end{align} \]
property R¶

c.f. pp 137 Ting, Elastic Anisotropy.

\[ \begin{align}\begin{aligned}R_{ik} = C_{i1k2}\\\begin{split}R = \begin{bmatrix} C_{16} & C_{12} & C_{14} \\ C_{66} & C_{26} & C_{46} \\ C_{56} & C_{25} & C_{45} \end{bmatrix}\end{split}\end{aligned}\end{align} \]
property T¶

c.f. pp 137 Ting, Elastic Anisotropy.

\[ \begin{align}\begin{aligned}T_{ij} = C_{i2k2}\\\begin{split}T = \begin{bmatrix} C_{66} & C_{26} & C_{46} \\ C_{26} & C_{22} & C_{24} \\ C_{46} & C_{24} & C_{44} \end{bmatrix}\end{split}\end{aligned}\end{align} \]
property a¶

Stroh eigenvectors (6,6) solutions to the fundamental elasticity matrix The eigenvector a represents the direction of the displacement.

c.f. Ting eqn. 5.5-4 & 5.3-11 NB scipy.linalg.eig returns column eigenvectors

apply_crystal_symmetry(group)[source]¶
apply_elastic_symmetry(X)[source]¶
apply_mandel(X)[source]¶

The extension of Voigt reduction to the 4th rank tensor representing proportionality of two 2nd rank tensors.

apply_voigt(X)[source]¶

Apply Voigt reduction scheme to X(3,3) to produce X2(6,). 11 -> 1; 22 -> 2; 33 -> 3; 23 -> 4; 13 -> 5; 12 -> 6

property cij: ndarray¶

Reduced stiffness matrix.

property cijkl: ndarray¶

Elastic stiffness tensor.

property crystalsystem¶
property elastic_symmetry¶

form symmetry equivalents ijks = jiks = ksij = ijsk

property eta¶

Left eigenvectors (6,6) of \(N^T \eta = p \eta\), see p.

\[\begin{split}\eta = \begin{bmatrix} l \\ a \\ \end{bmatrix}\end{split}\]
Ref:

Ting, T.C.T. (1996) Elastic Anisotropy. c.f. eqn. 5.5-3 pp. 144

invert_mandel(X, case='c')[source]¶

Given a Voigt reduced 2nd order tensor, reconstruct 4th order tensor.

invert_voigt(X)[source]¶

Given a Voigt reduced vector, reconstruct 2nd order tensor.

property l¶

Stroh eigenvectors (6,6) solutions to the fundamental elasticity matrix The eigenvector l represents the direction of traction.

c.f. Ting eqn. 5.5-4 & 5.3-11 NB scipy.linalg.eig returns column eigenvectors

property p¶

eigenvalues (6,) of the fundamental elasticity matrix

\[ \begin{align}\begin{aligned}N \xi = p \xi\\\begin{split}N = \begin{bmatrix} N_1 & N_2 \\ N_3 & N_1^T \end{bmatrix},\end{split}\\\begin{split}\xi = \begin{bmatrix} a \\ l \end{bmatrix}\end{split}\end{aligned}\end{align} \]
Ref:

Ting, T.C.T. (1996) Elastic Anisotropy. c.f. eqn. 5.5-3 pp. 144

classmethod reset()[source]¶

Reset class state.

property xi¶

Right eigenvectors (6,6) of \(N \xi = p \xi\), see p.

\[\begin{split}\xi = \begin{bmatrix} a \\ l \\ \end{bmatrix}\end{split}\]
Ref:

Ting, T.C.T. (1996) Elastic Anisotropy. c.f. eqn. 5.5-3 pp. 144
